name: Lazarus Group TTPs
description: TTPs used by the Lazarus Group in Operation Blacksmith

techniques.comment: Lazarus Group used at least three new DLang-based RATs, two of which employed Telegram bots and channels as a medium of command and control (C2) communications. The RATs were named NineRAT and DLRAT.
NineRAT re-fingerprinted infected systems, gathering initial information about the system, which indicated that the data collected via NineRAT may be shared by other APT groups.
Lazarus group exploited a known vulnerability (CVE-2021-44228) also known as Log4Shell, on publicly facing VMWare Horizon servers, as a means of initial access to vulnerable public-facing servers.
Lazarus group used a phishing attack to lead victims to malicious servers and collect their information.
NineRAT was self-destructible and could delete itself using a BAT script.
NineRAT fingerprinted the infected systems and gathered preliminary information.
The RAT executed command 'cmd.exe /C ipconfig /all' for network config discovery.
The Lazarus Group used a Telegram C2 channel for accepting commands and communicating.
Lazarus can deploy the RAT and other malware when required.
The dropper created a new service for the first component.
Lazarus Group created a new user account with administrative privileges on the victim’s system.
The APT group used a custom-made proxy called “HazyLoad” for direct access to the infected system.
NineRAT executed a command to receive the antivirus product's name.
Lazarus Group continued to target enterprises with vulnerable infrastructure.
Lazarus group used file transfer protocols to upload files to the C2.
After the successful setup of the user account, the attackers switched over to it and then began credential dumping for account details using MimiKatz and other utilities.
The attackers created a local account that had administrative privileges.
The attackers modified the registry to include credential logon settings.
